item.title: Setting up a Private PyPI Repository on the Google Cloud Platform
item.description: Every once in a while I am trying to solve a problem that is seemingly so fundamental that there must exist an off-the-shelf solution already. Setting up a private repository for Python packages on the Google Cloud Platform (GCP) falls into this category. But wait - almost every company produces source code that is not meant to become open-source, but needs to be distributed within the company. This can’t be that difficult, right?

item.title: 5 Lessons from Two Years of ML Engineering
item.description: Today, an increasing number of companies understand that data science isn‚Äôt just about presenting insights from data analysis to decision makers, but about building data science applications such as recommendation systems or spam filters. Thus, data science teams often not only consist of data scientists, but also of machine learning engineers who bridge the gap between data science and software engineering. I‚Äôm a machine learning engineer for two years now and want to share five lessons I‚Äôve learned while working on a variety of products.

item.title: Books
item.description: Behave, Robert Sapolsky A book of Rather Strange Animals: Highlights and Wonders of Evolution and the Extraordinary Diversity of Life, Caleb Compton How to Get Filthy Rich in Rising Asia: A Novel, Mohsin Hamid Children of Time, Adrian Tchaikovsky Blackout, Marc Elsberg How to Lie with Statistics, Darrel Huff Animal Farm, George Orwell

item.title: whois
item.description: üëè My name is Mike and I am a machine learning engineer living in Hamburg, Germany. I work for Otto Group data.works where I bridge data science and software engineering in e-commerce settings. I used to work for ThoughtWorks as a developer and consultant. Currently I work on products that use machine learning to enhance the online shopping experience and optimize business metrics. There, I am involved in every aspect of the design and implementation of real-world, data-driven services.

item.title: Thoughts on Pair Programming as the Default
item.description: Pair programming! Apparently, there is no other agile practice that divides the dev community as this one. On one side, there are the evangelists who advocate full-time pair programming as the only means to write high-quality software. There also exist companies like Pivotal that have made this view an integral part of their culture. On the other side, there are developers who insist to work quietly on their own. Developer misconception #1: I do my best work with headphones on
